across a bunch of calibration methods:

TLDR, they show that you can do significantly better (at least in some
cases) given the choice of data, but they don't look for any
algorithms for doing so (e.g. by examining margins).

email:
Hi everyone,

Many thanks a lot for your very interesting article. I have read it carefully, and would
have a few notes:

- First, the main findings seem generally valid in my experience, so it's nice to have them distilled in very clear form.
- However, for the comparison, specifically generation, I
think that it would be have been nice to compare with "state-of-the-art"
 techniques.
- One other variable that could be accounted for in more detail is how much
computation the user is willing to invest into the process. In
CAP (above) you can see that with 50% of the budget used for
finetuning one can reach 80-90% savings almost losslessly. Taking
this to the extreme, our work shows that one can reach highly-accurate networks with low accuracy drops (1-2%) provided enough compute is spent.

Anyway, I am aware that this short "critique" is biased towards my area
(and towards our own work), but I thought it might be useful to have this
perspective as well.

In any case, very nice work, and hopefully see you at the conference!

Cheers,
David

email:
Yes, that sounds great. I've put some talk details below.

Cheers,
David
Title: Accurate Deep Learning at Scale
Speaker: David Keys 

*Abstract: *A key barrier to the wide deployment of highly-accurate machine
learning models, whether for language or vision, is their high
computational and memory overhead. Although we possess the mathematical
tools for highly-accurate compression of such models, these
theoretically-elegant techniques require second-order information of the
model’s loss function, which is hard to even approximate efficiently at the
scale of billion-parameter models.In this talk, I will describe our work on
bridging this computational divide, which enables the accurate second-order
pruning and quantization of models at truly massive scale. Compressed using
our techniques, models with billions and even trillions of parameters can
be executed efficiently on a few GPUs, with significant speedups, and
negligible accuracy loss.
